text: Revolutionary!
author: mshannabrooks

text: I'm just going to start buying copies of Manufacturing Consent and mailing them to everyone in the city.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
It's not an organic reflection of how people feel. It's a reflection of how well propaganda works on people. 

And to say otherwise is irresponsible because it negates the role of the news media in our current climate.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
It's not just that people don't trust the City Council so they hang on to stories like this. 

It's that people have been told, by the news media in this town, not to trust the City Council, so they're primed for stories like this.
author: mshannabrooks

text: At present, in Seattle, a majority of the news media reporting does not reflect the way people feel—it is creating the way people feel and then echoing it back.
author: mshannabrooks

text: This story is a chicken/egg thing—the distrust of the City Council is BECAUSE of news reporting like this, and because people are so heated about, the news keeps drumming it up.
author: mshannabrooks

text: good lord.
author: mshannabrooks

text: She has a notably short temper. It's definitely going to be an issue for her campaign this season. Interestingly, when a man has the same thing (see: Ed Murray who was known for yelling at people) it's seen as powerful.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Public comment summarized in a gif.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Like it's not as though these public comments happen once a month. They happen multiple times a week. Every week.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Seriously, one of the hardest parts about being a City Councilmember is sitting for hours each week while you're berated and being expected to smile and nod the entire time.
author: mshannabrooks

text: I know, I meant Alex Tsimerman.
author: mshannabrooks

text: They conveniently do not mention that he testified just moments before the guy they're reporting on because lolololololol facts who cares
author: mshannabrooks

text: ...b.) we have a long history of people wasting the time of our elected officials with their Ham and Mayonnaise, and c.) this dude was previously known for kvetching about cyclists on KUOW. So.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Like if you're going to write a story about City Council public comment, be responsible and note that a.) council comment happens all the damn time and there's plenty of opportunity for people to say their piece...
author: mshannabrooks

text: This isn't to debate the politeness of checking emails during comment—though I have seen someone whose name rhymes with Moose Jarrell FALL ASLEEP more than once. It's about local news running with a ~Juicy Story~ that will make everyone mad! Without, you know, contextualizing.
author: mshannabrooks

text: And if you can't tell me that man's name, I do not care to hear your opinion about City Council public comment because you clearly have not been to one.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
As a person who has watched a LOT of public comment, I can tell you: A large amount of the public comment is.....................colorful. 

Like this is who testified a couple minutes before the guy in question.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Of note: Public comment, by the rule of Seattle, is required to pertain directly to the bills and issues being discussed unless otherwise specified by the chair. Here's the schedule for the 11th. Not sure that quoting Orwell counts?
author: mshannabrooks

text: It's kind of wild how much of local TV news is derived directly from Reddit. The story of the City Council and the guy who wanted them to pay attention is 100% because Redditors wanted to make it go viral and it worked.
author: mshannabrooks

text: <3 <3 <3 I see you!
author: mshannabrooks

text:
SVPD has a social media disclaimer which states that their goal is "to enhance communication, collaboration, information exchange, and transparency, streamline processes and foster productivity."

Tell me how sharing a Sinclair station's one-sided "report" achieves those goals.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
And on their social media disclaimer, their cited purpose is to "enhance and support SVPD program goals and objectives." So I'm not sure what else to read into it other that "as a department, they see this as in line with their goals."

https://www.spokanecounty.org/DocumentCenter/View/13013/SVPD-SocialMedia-?bidId= …
author: mshannabrooks

text: I mean, that's literally my job—I'm a contractor specifically for campaigns —so I know that before you post something like that you have to be pretty damn sure you have buy-in. A PIO is still a sworn officer and their job is to represent the department.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Also...this isn't a fringe group. This is literally the local police department. 

If you're a homeless person living in Spokane and you're, say, the victim of an assault, I would advise you not to call the cops. Because their department does not see you as a person.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
The news isn't supposed to tell you what you already think or make you feel better about what you believe to be true.

It's supposed to help you unpack it and contextualize it.
author: mshannabrooks

text: It's just really dangerous when news stations broadcast one-sided propaganda that can actively harm people and then all of the people and groups who have been frothing at the mouth for exactly such a piece of propaganda feel validated and emboldened in their position.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Better; I don't think I'd have gotten hired. But even the prep for Sinclair was awful—scrubbing websites, deleting stuff, firing the more "troublesome" employees. First thing Sinclair did was union-bust. The second thing they did was suppress the wages of the salaried workers.
author: mshannabrooks

author: mshannabrooks

text:
There's a really ugly chair outside of my apartment building. A homeowner put it in their driveway last night and then, it seems, moved it **around the corner** in front of my stoop. 

Further proof that it's not just folks without homes who leave their crap all over the place.
author: mshannabrooks

text: That's about the read I had.
author: mshannabrooks

text: That would be amazing and will never happen.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
KOMO made a choice to do the opposite. To ~shock people~ into, what? More fear? More othering?

Because I don't see a whole lot of empathy being ginned up by filming people without their consent and playing spooky music under it. 

BOO. Boo all of that.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
What we haven't heard? And what would be like, I don't know, actually beneficial to the community?

Is a story about how to keep your heart tender and see people for what they are—not "junkies," not "crazies," but human beings, whose pain is as real as yours, and who need help.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
This is not, like out, of nowhere. In KOMO's teaser, they advertised that they'd talk to a group "that you haven't heard from."

That group? Homeowners afraid to take their kids to the park because they might see visible poverty. 

Pretty sure we've heard from them a whole lot.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Here's a book. 

http://flashlightpress.com/maddis-fridge/ 

Buy it and read it to your kids.
author: mshannabrooks

text: I genuinely believe that a lot of homeowners in Seattle see them as the same thing—that seeing a person in a tent or sleeping in a park is akin to living in a war zone.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
There are homeless students all over Seattle today. Your kid probably as at least one homeless student in their class. 

Seems like something you'd WANT to explain to them.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Two, you do realize that until like, 100 years ago, one of the biggest homeless populations was literal children? That seems like a good way to talk about it, too. Because it was solved not by locking them up, but by increasing services. 

http://povertyhistory.org/era/nineteenth/
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Two things: One, it's really not that hard to explain if you had a grain of empathy. Tell your kids that sometimes people need help and it's not there and hey, let's go email our lawmakers. 

That's only hard if you refuse to acknowledge that people sometimes need a hand up.
author: mshannabrooks

text: There is this thing that people say a lot in Safe Seattle and on NextDoor—which is baked into the premise of this piece—about how awful it is to see homeless folks. They ask often, how do I explain it to my kids?!?! They shouldn't have to see that!
author: mshannabrooks

text: It's a pretty good example, though, of how "unbiased" news media is actually extremely biased. I saw the list of people they talked to and consulted. I can assure you: They are really quite biased.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
I did not watch KOMO's ~special report~ on homelessness because I used to work at that station & know the preconceived notions a lot of people who work there have about homeless folks. 

Also because I don't really need to see a dramatic reenactment of a Safe Seattle thread.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
I think the "losing battle" rhetoric, though, makes people feel better because there's still a big bad monster or enemy to blame. 

Their loved one didn't make a choice. Instead, they fought a battle. And lost. 

Just a thought I was having.
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Depression isn't a battle, it's just like...a way your brain works. You can't win or lose to it—it's not a game. 

You can only live with it, or not live with it. And if we're going to admit that it's a choice that some people make, we might as well allow them some agency.
author: mshannabrooks

text: (I'm doing nighttime research and I'm finding that this is becoming more common as more people are willing to acknowledge that suicide is a way that people die which is step one, I guess?)
author: mshannabrooks

text:
Perhaps it's a personal thing but I really hate it when someone ends their life and their obit or family or whoever says they "lost their battle with depression."

People who die by suicide aren't losers. They're people who were in pain.
author: mshannabrooks

text: Pretty neat that they erected that monument to your nightmares.
author: mshannabrooks
